unnormalised: So, someone asked about common misconceptions in Obstetrics & Gynecology. Buckle up, folks, because this field is basically a minefield of old wives' tales and stuff your Dadi probably told you.
normalised: So, someone asked about common misconceptions in Obstetrics and Gynecology. Buckle up, folks, because this field is basically a minefield of old wives' tales and stuff your Dadi probably told you.

unnormalised: First off, let's talk about period pain. The myth that "it's all in your head" or "it's just part of being a woman" needs to be yeeted into the sun. Dysmenorrhea is a real thing, and sometimes it requires more than just a hot water bag and some chai. If you're popping 5-6 Ibuprofen 400mg a day just to function, please see a gyno. seriously.
normalised: First off, let's talk about period pain. The myth that "it's all in your head" or "it's just part of being a woman" needs to be yeeted into the sun. Dysmenorrhea is a real thing, and sometimes it requires more than just a hot water bag and some chai. If you're popping five to six Ibuprofen four hundred milligram a day just to function, please see a gyno, seriously.

unnormalised: Then there's the whole "eating for two" thing during pregnancy. Look, you're growing a human, not a small village. You need extra nutrients, sure, but not 2x the parathas. Talk to your doctor about a healthy pregnancy diet – probably avoid the extra butter chicken once a week as a 'treat' (sorry folks). Aim for an extra 300-400 calories, not the entire menu of Haldiram’s.

Talk to your doctor about a healthy pregnancy diet, probably avoid the extra butter chicken once a week as a 'treat' (sorry folks). Aim for an extra three hundred to four hundred calories, not the entire menu of Haldiram's.

unnormalised: Another gem: “once a C-section, always a C-section.” While VBACs (Vaginal Birth After Cesarean) have risks, they are often a viable option. Talk to your doctor about your options and whether you are a good candidate. Dr. Sharma at AIIMS Delhi specializes in VBAC and has a success rate of 70%. Just saying…
normalised: Another gem: “once a C-section, always a C-section.” While V-B-A-C-s (Vaginal Birth After Cesarean) have risks, they are often a viable option. Talk to your doctor about your options and whether you are a good candidate. Doctor Sharma at A-I-I-M-S Delhi specializes in V-B-A-C and has a success rate of seventy percent. Just saying…

unnormalised: And of course, the big one: "you'll get pregnant if you even LOOK at a boy!". While I applaud the optimistic spirit of this myth, it's not quite true. There are many forms of contraception available, from condoms to IUDs to pills. Consult with your gyno to find one that works for you. Don't rely on prayers and good intentions alone (unless your prayers have a prescription pad).

unnormalised: Oh, and let’s not forget the “prepone” pregnancy announcement nonsense. You're not a train departure, you're a miracle! There's no need to rush things or tell everyone by week 12 unless YOU want to. Your body, your business.
normalised: Oh, and let’s not forget the “prepone” pregnancy announcement nonsense. You're not a train departure, you're a miracle! There's no need to rush things or tell everyone by week twelve unless YOU want to. Your body, your business.

unnormalised: And seriously, stop believing everything you read on the internet (yes, even this post...sort of). If you have concerns about your reproductive health, see a real-life, qualified gynecologist. Googling "vaginal discharge home remedies" is not a substitute for a proper diagnosis. Your bits and bobs will thank you for it.

unnormalised: Lastly, the thought that if you can get pregnant easily, you can get pregnant easily the second time. One lady who had her first baby at 24 with relative ease assumed conceiving her second at 34, would be just as easy. A year and a half later, and consulting with a fertility specialist, she was shocked and wished she had tried a little earlier. Remember, everyone is different and every pregnancy is different.

unnormalised: Basically, take everything with a grain of salt, consult experts, and remember, your body is a temple (a temple that sometimes needs a good scrubbing and some professional maintenance from a qualified OB/GYN). Good luck out there!
